poem:
Village Dance

In dreams, sound weaves  
Anoushka moves through echoes,  
sitar whispers mix with breath—  
Tana Mana swirls, a dance unseen,  
Ravi's notes rise, reincarnate in  
synthesizer hum, lattice of past  
and present—imagination sets  
the village aglow—silent words  
unspoken, yet understood in  
each chord's quivering embrace.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I was the only person who didn’t know the words to Coldplay’: Anoushka Shankar’s honest playlist The first song I fell in love withTana Mana by my dad, Ravi Shankar. In the late 80s he was experimenting with synthesisers and released an album called Tana Mana, an anomaly in his discography. I remember my imagination would light up with the title song – I would picture a village dance, and I’d be acting it out". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
